Graphical abstract Highlights ► The presence of Ga as an additive on NiW/-γ-Al2O3 catalysts was investigated. ► Gallium induced significant increases on HDS activities for DBT and 4,6-DMDBT reactions. ► Ni promotion in the NiWS phase close to 100% was obtained for a NiWS/Ga-γ-Al2O3 catalyst containing 2.4wt.% Ga. The effect of gallium over the NiW/γ-Al2O3 catalyst was investigated in the hydrodesulfurization (HDS) of 4,6-dimethyl-dibenzothiophene (4,6-DMDBT). The alumina carrier was modified with gallium by the addition of an aqueous solution of Ga(NO3)3·H2O in order to obtain supports with a nominal composition between 0.0 and 3.0wt.% of Ga. The Ni–W catalysts were prepared with respectively 2.8 W atoms and 1.9 Ni atoms per nm2 of initial surface area for the alumina support. The catalysts were characterized by different techniques such as temperature-programmed reduction, X-ray diffraction, UV–vis, Raman spectroscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy and transmission electron microscopy and they were evaluated in the HDS of 4,6-DMDBT. The highest HDS activity for NiW catalysts was observed when the amount of gallium was 2.4wt.%, improving the value by ca. 90% as compared with that for the NiW gallium-free catalyst. This result was correlated to the effect of Ga over the dispersion of W and Ni entities. Indeed, the amount of WO x particles calculated by the Raman (OWO+WO)/WOW band intensities ratio was the highest for NiW/Ga(2.4)-γ-catalyst and HRTEM examination on the sulfided catalysts showed a decrease for the average stacking number and for the average length of WS2 particles with the gallium content. Moreover, change of the promoter (Ni2+) interaction with the support was induced by the affinity of gallium (at low loadings) to the tetrahedral sites of alumina, inducing an increase of the octahedral species of Ni in the oxidic state of the catalysts as evidenced from UV–vis and to a higher amount of the NiWS mixed phase in the sulfided samples as deduced from XPS analysis. Keywords Hydrodesulfurization NiW Gallium 4,6-Dimethyldibenzothiophene TPR XPS Raman spectroscopy HRTEM 1 Introduction The high demand for diesel fuels with less than 10wppm of sulfur implies to achieve high conversions in hydrotreatment (HDT) units [1,2]. Therefore, the challenge in deep hydrodesulfurization (HDS) is to convert the most refractory sulfur species such as 4,6-dimethyldibenzothiophene (4,6-DMDBT) [3,4]. Moreover, the presence of nitrogen-containing and aromatic compounds must be considered due to their inhibiting effect on the HDS reaction [5,6]. In this line, the nickel–tungsten–alumina (NiW/γ-Al2O3) catalysts are particularly relevant owing to their outstanding catalytic actions in hydrogenation (HYD) and hydrodenitrogenation (HDN) reactions. Commercial NiW/γ-Al2O3 catalysts are mostly prepared by impregnation of nickel and tungsten solutions over γ-Al2O3. The polytungstate anions adsorb electrostatically on the alumina surface [7] and they react with the hydroxyl groups, producing a strong metal–support interaction after calcination. However, a recent paper [8] proposed that several phases coexist in the NiW oxide samples and that their relative concentrations depend on the Ni/(Ni+W) atomic ratio and on the W loading. From characterization for WO3 and NiO–WO3 catalysts supported on alumina by X-ray diffraction (XRD) [9], X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) [7] and Raman spectroscopy [10–12] it is now well established that W species are generally highly dispersed and thus, the anchor AlOW is highly stable. Due to this interaction, the surface species formed on NiO–WO3/γ-Al2O3 catalysts are difficult to sulfide as previously evidenced by temperature-programmed sulfiding (TPS) [13], infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy of adsorbed NO (FT-IR(NO)) and by quasi in situ XPS [14] experiments. Therefore, the role of the support is fundamental in order to synthesize highly active NiWS catalysts. One way to obtain that could be to modify the surface properties of the alumina in order to decrease the tungsten–alumina interaction, since easier sulfidable species could be synthesized. Studies by FT-IR(NO) [14], TPS, XPS [15], quick extended X-ray absorption fine structure (QEXAFS), X-ray absorption near-edge structure spectroscopy (XANES) [16] and nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) [17] have shown that fluorination of alumina modified the interaction of tungsten with the support increasing the sulfidation of this metal. Also, it has been published that, at low concentrations, gallium decreased the interaction of Ni [18] with γ-Al2O3, due to the high affinity of Ga3+ to the tetrahedral sites of alumina, modifying the ratio of N i tet 2 + / N i oct 2 + species. Furthermore, it has been found that gallium induced relevant changes in the interaction of NiMo with γ-Al2O3 [19–21] and it increased their activity in the HDS of dibenzothiophene (DBT) and 4,6-DMDBT [19,21]. In a previous work some of us reported that gallium addition on a commercial alumina carrier affected significantly its surface [22]. The presence of at least two gallium species was proposed, GaAl2O4 species decreasing the isoelectric point (IEP) at low gallium content and the formation of Ga2O3 at high contents, increasing the IEP. The highest amount of irregular WO x particles, calculated from the Raman (OWO+WO)/WOW band intensities ratio, was observed for the catalyst leading to the higher activity in the dibenzothiophene hydrodesulfurization reaction. As a continuation of the previous work we decided to explore the gallium effect on the NiW system supported on alumina. This effect was studied on a series of nickel–tungsten catalysts supported on alumina with a gallium content ranging from 0 to 3% wt. These catalysts were tested on the HDS of DBT in a batch reactor and on the HDS of 4,6-DMDBT in a continuous flow reactor. These results are discussed considering the characterization by Raman spectroscopy, UV–vis, TPR, XPS and HRTEM. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The supports were prepared by pore filling impregnation at equilibrium pH of a commercial γ-Al2O3 [high purity, BET surface area 260m2 g−1, pore volume (V p) 0.66cm3 g−1 and particle size 80–120μm] with appropriate aqueous solutions of Ga(NO3)3·xH2O (Aldrich Chemical, 99.9%) to obtain supports with 0, 0.6, 0.9, 1.2, 1.8, 2.4 and 3.0wt.% of Ga. After 12h, the obtained solids were dried at 393K for 12h and calcined at 723K for 4h under a flow of air (5.16×10−3 molmin−1) with a heating rate of 1Kmin−1. NiW catalysts were prepared by successive impregnation of the calcined Ga/γ-Al2O3 supports using the pore filling method with aqueous solutions of ammonium metatungstate (AMTW) ((NH4)6W12O39·xH2O, Aldrich Chemical, 99.99%) and nickel nitrate (Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, Aldrich Chemical, 99.99%). Ammonium metatungstate impregnation was performed at pH=3.7 (natural solution) and impregnation of nickel was performed with the solution of nickel nitrate at pH=4.4. For tungsten and nickel 2.8 and 1.9 atoms per nm2 of initial surface area of alumina were respectively added, leading to an atomic ratio r =Ni/(Ni+W) equal to 0.41. In a typical preparation, the solution of AMTW was first impregnated on the support, left for maceration for 12h, and then the solid was dried under a stream of air (5.16×10−3 molmin−1) at 393K for 12h, with a heating rate of 3Kmin−1. Then Ni was impregnated under the same conditions and the final solid was calcined at 723K for 4h under a flow of air (5.16×10−3 molmin−1) with a heating rate of 1Kmin−1. The catalysts will be denoted as NiW/Ga(x)-γ-Al2O3, x being the weight percent of gallium introduced. A series of Ni/Ga(x)-γ-Al2O3 materials was also prepared by the pore filling method on the calcined Ga/γ-Al2O3 supports with the corresponding aqueous solution. Loading of the metal was the same than that present in the NiW catalysts. Solids were dried at 393K for 12h and calcined at 723K for 4h under a flow of air (5.16×10−3 molmin−1) with a heating rate of 1Kmin−1. The samples will be denoted as Ni/Ga(x)-γ-Al2O3. 2.2 Characterization techniques After calcination, the metal contents were determined by plasma coupled atomic emission spectroscopy (AES-ICP) after appropriate dissolution of the solid samples. Raman spectra were obtained at room temperature on a T64000 triple monochromator (Jobin-Yvon-Horiba) using the 514.5nm line of an Ar+ laser (Lexel Laser). All the spectra were obtained at a power of 10mW at the laser head, in the range 10–1600cm−1, using an Olympus microscope with a ×100 objective and 10 accumulations of 60s each. The spectrum resolution was 1cm−1. Gaussian decomposition of spectra was carried out with appropriate commercial software. The oxide catalysts were sulfided at 673K for 2h with a mixture of H2S/H2 (10% H2S) by using a total flow rate of 2.97×10−3 molmin−1 and a heating rate of 5Kmin−1. After this step, the catalysts were cooled to room temperature and flushed with N2 for about half an hour and kept in sealed bottles under argon. For the XPS measurements the sulfided samples were transferred into a glove box without air exposure and under the presence of argon to avoid the contact with air. The samples were pressed on an indium foil attached to the sample holder and transported into the preparation chamber of the XPS machine. The XPS spectra were recorded on a VG Instrument type ESCALAB 200R system. The sample excitation was done by Al Kα X-rays (1486.6eV). Peak shifts due to charging of the samples were corrected by taking the Al 2p line of Al2O3 at 74.0eV as a reference. High resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) examinations were performed with a JEOL 2010 (200kV) instrument equipped with a Link ISIS micro-analysis system. Its resolution was 0.195nm. Freshly sulfided catalyst samples were ultrasonically dispersed in an ethanol solution at room temperature and the suspensions were collected on a carbon-coated copper grid. In the sulfided state, alumina-supported W catalysts exhibit WS2 slabs building a layered structure. The average number of layers per stack and the average stack length were calculated from examination of more than 800 particles, the statistical studies were made according to Eqs. (1) and (2) [23–25] respectively: (1) N ¯ = ∑ i = 1 n n i N i ∑ i = 1 n n i (2) L ¯ = ∑ i = 1 n n i l i ∑ i = 1 n n i where l i is the length of slab-particle i, n i the number of particles with a l i length or N i layers, and N i the number of layers in the particle i. 2.3 Catalytic activity measurements The HDS of DBT (Aldrich Chemical, 98%) was performed in a 500mL batch reactor, magnetically stirred (1200rpm) (Parr Instrument Co.) equipped with four baffles on the wall to prevent vortex formation. The conditions of the tests were as follows: temperature of 593K under an hydrogen atmosphere of 5MPa, using 250mg of sulfided catalyst and 1.22×10−3 mol of DBT dissolved in 100mL hexadecane (Aldrich Chemical, 99%). The reactor was flushed with nitrogen and heated under stirring to reach the reaction temperature, hydrogen was then introduced (P tot =5MPa). The reaction time was counted from this moment. The total pressure was controlled constantly during the course of the reaction by adding hydrogen to compensate for its consumption. Samples were periodically collected and analyzed quantitatively by gas chromatography. The catalytic activity was expressed by the initial reaction rate (mol DBT transformed per second and per gram of catalyst). The HDS of 4,6-DMDBT (Aldrich Chemical, 97%) was carried out in a three-phases continuous flow microreactor with dodecane (Aldrich Chemical, 99%) as solvent, working at 3 different temperatures (553, 573, and 593K) and using two different flows to avoid high conversions (F 1 =9.51×10−7 and F 2 =13.75×10−7 mol of 4,6-DMDBTs−1) with an H2 pressure of 3MPa, and a H2 flow of 4.3×10−3 lmin−1. Every catalytic test was done with a previous stabilization step for 10–12h at 593K. Then 6 samples were collected and systematically analyzed to verify steady state operation, after that, temperature was decreased to 553K and then the previous procedure was repeated. Then temperature was increased gradually to 573K and finally 593K again to verify a possible deactivation. In all cases the reaction rate was calculated at steady state operation. The catalyst weight was approximately 50mg. The products were analyzed by GC and all the rates were estimated at low conversion (<15%). For the HDS of DBT, the obtained products were biphenyl (89%) followed by cyclohexyl benzene (10%) and negligible traces of dicyclohexyl. On the case of HDS reaction of 4,6-DMDBT the main products were methylcyclohexyl toluene, 3,3′-dimethylcyclohexyl, and 3,3′-dimethylbiphenyl. No evidence of cracking products that could be volatile at sampling conditions as benzene, cyclohexane, toluene or methyl cyclohexane was observed. For both HDS reactions, H2S is the only gaseous product; nevertheless quantification of this was not necessary for our reaction rate analysis since it could be deduced from the stoichiometry. 3 Results 3.1 Catalytic activities of NiW/Ga(x)-γ-Al2O3 catalysts on the HDS of DBT The influence of gallium loading on the activity for NiW/Ga(x)-γ-Al2O3 catalysts in the HDS of DBT reaction is depicted in Fig. 1 . The results show that addition of gallium to alumina led to an almost linear increase of activity for Ga contents up to 2.4 and then a decrease occurred for higher Ga loadings. The NiW/Ga(2.4)-γ-Al2O3 sample exhibited a 3-fold activity increase compared with that for the gallium-free solid. The distribution of products was approximately the same for all NiW/Ga(x)-γ-Al2O3 catalysts series. At 40% total conversion, the main product was biphenyl (89%) followed by cyclohexyl benzene (10%) and negligible traces of dicyclohexyl. 3.2 Catalytic activities of NiW/Ga(x)-γ-Al2O3 catalysts on the HDS of 4,6-DMDBT Reaction results for HDS of 4,6-DMDBT carried out in a continuous flow reactor are given in Table 1 . At low gallium content, 4 and 12% higher activities respectively were observed for NiW/Ga(0.6.)-γ-Al2O3 and NiW/Ga(1.2.)-γ-Al2O3 catalysts, than that for the gallium-free catalyst. Moreover, the activity increases were even higher for the NiW/Ga(1.8.)-γ-Al2O3 and NiW/Ga(2.4)-γ-Al2O3 samples (43% and 73% respectively). The NiW/Ga(2.4)-γ-Al2O3 solid appeared to be the most active catalyst for the HDS of 4,6-DMDBT reaction and for the HDS of DBT. The main products for the HDS of 4,6-DMDBT were methylcyclohexyl toluene, 3,3-dimethylcyclohexyl, and 3,3-dimethylbiphenyl. Taking into account that transformation of 4,6-DMDBT occurs through two parallel routes (the direct desulfurization, DDS, and the hydrogenation, HYD) [26–28] methyl cyclohexyl toluene and 3,3-dimethylcyclohexyl were considered as products of the HYD pathway and 3,3-dimethylbiphenyl was taken into account for the DDS route. We observed changes in the NiW catalysts selectivities as a function of the amount of gallium and the increment for the DDS route can be probably related to an increase in the formation of the NiWS mixed phase. 3.3 Raman spectroscopy of NiW/Ga(x)-γ-Al2O3 catalysts. The Raman spectra for the NiW/Ga(x) calcined catalysts (Fig. 2 ) exhibited two main bands centered approximately at 550cm−1 and 960cm−1. In a previous work, it was shown [22] that the broad band observed in the region 740–1060cm−1can be composed of four peaks related with the vibrational modes of WO [29–34]. These bands were considered to perform the Gaussian decomposition of the spectra and they allowed us to obtain the ratio between integrated peak areas for terminals bonds OWO and WO (bands centered at 940–950 and 970–990cm−1 respectively) and areas for internal WOW bonds (bands at 800–810cm−1) [22,35]. The results presented in Fig. 3 showed that this ratio increased from 1.45 for the gallium-free catalyst to 2.5, 4.43, and 5.00, for the catalysts supported on carriers containing 0.6, 1.2, 1.8 and 2.4wt.% Ga respectively. After the maximum band intensities ratio observed for the catalyst NiWO x /Ga(2.4)-γ-Al2O3 sample, we noted a decrease to 3.56 for the catalyst containing 3.0wt.% Ga. The other broad band between 436 and 671cm−1 and centered approximately at 550cm−1 could be related to vibrations for some NiO species in this region. These Ni species could be assigned to crystalline NiAl2O4 with vibrations peaks approximately at 840, 620, 375 and 200cm−1. Signals at 460 and 500cm−1 have been related to tetrahedral NiO species and those between 500 and 600 centered approximately at 555cm−1 correlated to NiO octahedral species [36,37]. In order to get more insight about Ni species, Raman spectroscopy and temperature programmed reduction (TPR-H2) analyses for Ni/Ga(x)-γ-Al2O3 calcined materials were carried out. 3.3.1 Raman spectroscopy for Ni/Ga(x)-γ-Al2O3 catalysts. On the expanded scale spectra given in Fig. 4 the presence of vibrations between 350cm−1 and 675cm−1 can be observed for Ni/Ga(0.0)-γ-Al2O3 and Ni/Ga(1.2)-γ-Al2O3 samples. These peaks can be clearly assigned; the vibration between 350 and 500cm−1 corresponding probably to tetrahedral NiO and the second one between 500 and 675cm−1 centered at 560cm−1 can be related with octahedral NiO [36,37]. Vibrations corresponding to the crystalline NiAl2O4 were not detected. A significant increase on intensities for both vibrations was observed for the Ni/Ga(1.2)-γ-Al2O3 sample. This increase was more important for the region corresponding to the octahedral NiO x species. The Raman bands intensities ratio Nitet/Nioct for the Ni/Ga(x)-γ-Al2O3 calcined samples was therefore calculated. The ratio Nitet/Nioct was 0.60 for the Ni/Ga(0.0)-γ-Al2O3 catalyst and only 0.39 for Ni/Ga(1.2)-γ-Al2O3 sample. These results explain well the observations on the NiW/Ga(x)-γ-Al2O3 materials presented before and they allowed us to confirm the affinity of Ga for the tetrahedral sites of the alumina, as early published by Cimino et al. [18]. 3.3.2 TPR for Ni/Ga(x)-γ-Al2O3 materials TPR analyses for Ni/Ga(0.0)-γ-Al2O3, Ni/Ga(0.9)-γ-Al2O3 and Ni/Ga(1.2)-γ-Al2O3 Ga(1.2)-γ-Al2O3, γ-Al2O3 and γ-Ga2O3 materials are presented in Fig. 5 (spectra A, B, C, D, E and F respectively). It can be observed that the main reduction peak started at 633K for the Ni/Ga(0.0)-γ-Al2O3, Ni/Ga(0.9)-γ-Al2O3 and Ni/Ga(1.2)-γ-Al2O3 samples. The symmetry of the peak until ca. 900K would indicate probably a homogeneous distribution of Ni species on the surface. Ga incorporation increased the intensity of the signal suggesting an increase on the quantity of NiO x on the surface. We can also observe a slight increase on the temperature at the maxima of the reduction peak from 810K on the gallium free sample (A) to 824K and 830K for the samples Ni/Ga(0.9)-γ-Al2O3 and Ni/Ga(1.2)-γ-Al2O3 respectively. This increase could mean that the interaction between Ni and support was stronger with the Ga content, indicating higher dispersion for NiO species for the Ga-containing samples. Also a second small shoulder apparently centered between 1069K and 1083K was observed for these 3 samples. This shoulder could be related to the presence of NiAl2O4 on the gallium-free sample. However the possible formation of GaAl2O4 could be suggested, as we reported in a previous work dealing with supports with gallium as an additive [22]. In the literature it is accepted that three types of Ni species could exist over alumina support: the NiO bulk or free NiO (reduction temperature (Tr)<673K), NiO bonded to Al2O3 (reduction temperature 673–963K) and NiO incorporated into Al2O3, probably as NiAl2O4 due to migration phenomena (Tr>973K), with the maximum reduction temperature in the range of 1053–1103K [38,39]. In order to get further insight into the Ni species, the Ga(1.2)-γ-Al2O3 support and γ-Ga2O3 as references were analyzed by TPR. Alumina carrier did not exhibit any reduction peak. For the γ-Ga2O3 the TPR profile showed a reduction starting at ca. 653K, then the signal increased slightly until ca. 900K and finally it decreased in agreement with literature data [40]. The TPR profile for the Ga(1.2)-γ-Al2O3 sample showed a symmetric reduction peak between 793K and 1033K with a maximum at 998K. According to these results, it is possible to consider that the shoulder at ca. 1073K in the TPR spectra could be related to the formation of stoichiometric spinels of GaAl2O4 for the Ni/Ga(0.9)-γ-Al2O3 and Ni/Ga(1.2)-γ-Al2O3 samples. Nevertheless the presence of small quantities of NiAl2O4 cannot be ruled out since this shoulder was also detected on the Ni/Ga(0.0)-γ-Al2O3 profile. 3.4 Diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (DRS) UV–vis of NiW/Ga(x)-γ-Al2O3 catalysts Fig. 6A presents the DRS spectra of the calcined NiW/Ga(x)-γ-Al2O3 samples. A slight shift on the absorption edge for materials was detected, due to the presence of gallium and at least two absorption bands can be observed: a strong absorption with a maximum centered at approximately 280nm and a weak absorption near to 440nm. The first band between 200 and 400nm is due to O2− →W6+ charge transfer transitions corresponding to the excitation of electrons from the valence band to the conduction band. In this region the presence of tetrahedral species between 200 and 300nm and octahedral species between 300 and 480nm are generally considered [41]. Moreover, details of these spectra given in Fig. 6B showed that the incorporation of gallium to alumina support induced an inflection point near 280nm on spectra for NiW/Ga(0.9)-γ-Al2O3, NiW/Ga(1.8)-γ-Al2O3 and NiW/Ga(2.4)-γ-Al2O3 solids. This inflection point is assigned to an increase on the absorption band associated with octahedral species. Indeed it has been reported in the literature that the absorption edge energy of crystalline WO x species depends on the number of WO x neighbors bonded through WOW bonds and by the number of bonds between each polyhedra [31]. Thus, a variation on the absorption edge can be related to the size of WO x polytungtates. Therefore, the increase on the absorption edge for our samples can be related to a slight decrease of the size of WO x supported particles, pointing out to an increase on the interaction between tungsten oxide species and support. The second weak absorption between 380 and 450nm can be assigned to Ni2+ octahedral species (Nioct 2+) which are associated with the promotion of the active sulfide phase [14]. Indeed, in Fig. 6C it is possible to observe a clear variation with the gallium content for the Nioct 2+ assigned band. This band showed the maximum intensity for catalyst NiW/Ga(2.4)-γ-Al2O3, which confirms our conclusions obtained by Raman spectroscopy and TPR analyses. A higher proportion of nickel available for the promotion of WS2 active phase could be suggested for the mentioned-above sample. 3.5 XPS characterization 3.5.1 XPS spectra for the W4f emission line region Fig. 7a depicts XPS spectra for the W4f core level for NiW/Ga(x)-γ-Al2O3 sulfided catalysts. Three peaks can be observed at about 32.4, 34.5 and 38.0eV on all obtained spectra. For such materials the decomposition process is well documented in the literature and it considers usually the overlapping of characteristic doublets, arising from the electrons of the W4f7/2 and W4f5/2 levels related to W6+, W5+ and W4+ species. The W5+ oxidation state corresponds to oxisulfides (WO x S y ) species which have been recognized as intermediates in the sulfidation process. The binding energies for the W4f5/2 and W4f7/2 levels related with these W species were considered at 35.6 and 37.8eV for W6+ [42], at 32.2 and 34.4eV for W4+ species [14,42–44], and at 33.5 and 37.7eV for the W5+ species [14,45,46]. An example of such decomposition is given in Fig. 7b, and Table 2 reports the relative concentrations for each species from the decomposition for NiWS/Ga(x)-γ-Al2O3 materials. On the NiWS/Ga(0.0%)-γ-Al2O3 sample, 81% of available W entities were converted into WS2 species. This quantity decreased apparently with the presence of Ga, changing to 74% and 69% for NiWS/Ga(1.2%)-γ-Al2O3 and NiWS/Ga(2.4%)-γ-Al2O3 respectively. By contrast the W6+ species increased from 10% for the gallium-free sample to 13% and 17% for NiWS/Ga(1.2%)-γ-Al2O3 and NiWS/Ga(2.4%)-γ-Al2O3 catalysts respectively. For oxisulfides species also the semi-quantitative results showed a similar behavior. Such results could mean that the presence of gallium increased the interaction of the alumina support with the WO x species. Thus, the degree of sulfidation of these materials decreased. 3.5.2 XPS spectra for the Ni2p emission line region The XPS spectra for Ni2p emission line of the NiWS/Ga(x)-γ-Al2O3 catalysts are given in Fig. 8C–E. For the three samples we can observe the presence of a main peak centered at about 854eV and another one with less intensity centered at ca. 861.4eV, in agreement with previous work by Reinhoudt et al. [14]. On the surface of these sulfide catalysts, Ni may exist as Ni(II) (NiO x ; sulfided Ni(II) species are not included here), NiS x (Ni2S3, Ni9S8, NiS) and NiWS. However, as far as we know, satisfactory decomposition process was never reported on this region for NiWS sulfide catalysts. In order to get a quantification of these different Ni chemical states onto the catalytic systems, the decomposition of Ni2p spectra of the different catalytic systems has been undertaken using a methodology previously developed by Gandubert et al. [47] and it is explained below. A monometallic sample Ni/Ga(1.2)-γ-Al2O3 was prepared on the Ga(1.2)-γ-Al2O3 support with the same Ni content as in the NiWS/Ga(1.2)-γ-Al2O3 catalyst and taken as reference for NiO x species. From the decomposition procedure, nickel oxide species at low (858.4eV) and high (855.6eV) binding energies were obtained and a shake-up satellite was considered for each of those peaks (Fig. 8A). Then this solid was sulfided at 400°C under 15% H2S-H2 to obtain the reference sample for NiS x contributions. The curves from decomposition for Ni/Ga(1.2)-γ-Al2O3 oxide material were taken and setting into the spectrum of the Ni/Ga(1.2)-γ-Al2O3 sulfide sample and the reconstruction of the Ni2p3/2 spectral envelope is achieved by positioning the fully Ni sulfided species at 853eV and adding two satellite peaks at 855.1eV and 859.2eV (Fig. 8B). The obtained value for the NiS was fairly close to the ones reported in the literature [48–53]. These two precedent fits for the Ni/Ga(1.2)-γ-Al2O3 sample in oxide and sulfur states were taken and they were introduced into the spectrum for the NiWS/Ga(x)-γ-Al2O3 catalysts. It clearly appeared that a third contribution was necessary to fit correctly the Ni2p3/2 emission region. Thus a peak for NiWS species at 853.9eV and one shake up satellite were added (Fig. 8C–E). This process previously applied for NiMo and CoMo [54–56] sulfided catalyst allowed us to perform a satisfactory fit for our XPS spectra, using the parameters listed in Table 3 . The quantitative results are presented in Table 4 . It is clear that in the Ni/Ga(1.2)-γ-Al2O3 catalyst 16% of NiO x species still remained after the sulfidation process. By contrast, on NiWS/Ga(1.2)-γ-Al2O3 catalyst the NiO x percentage decreased considerably (1%). On the same material, also a decrease on NiS species was detected passing from 84% to 36%. Besides, the amount of nickel species promoting the tungsten sulfide active phase increased with the gallium content, starting from 58% for the gallium free sample to 63% and 75% for NiWS/Ga(1.2)-γ-Al2O3 and NiWS/Ga(2.4)-γ-Al2O3 respectively. 3.6 HRTEM analysis Typical HRTEM micrographs for the NiW/Ga(0.0)-γ-Al2O3 and NiW/Ga(2.4)-γ-Al2O3 catalysts showing the presence of WS2 lamellar structure are presented in Fig. 9 . It appears that WS2 crystallites were well dispersed, with slabs often bent on a long scale, suggesting strong interaction with the support. For each individual crystallite two parameters have been considered: the length L of the black lines which arises from crystal viewed along the basal plane direction and it represents the lattice image from WS2 slabs and the number N of three-dimensional stacked layers. Such values were determined for about 800–1000 crystallites detected on 10 HRTEM micrographs for each catalyst and means values were calculated using Eqs. (1) and (2). The observed spacing between the lines of about 0.61nm is consistent with the interplanar spacing for bulk WS2 (0.61–0.62nm) reported on the literature [23,24]. At simple view, it is possible to observe that in the NiWS/Ga(2.4)-γ-Al2O3 there was a lower proportion of multilayer crystallites and these exhibited smaller size than those presented on the NiWS/Ga(0.0)-γ-Al2O3 catalyst. With the statistical analysis it could be verified that the average of stacking layer for NiWS/Ga(2.4)-γ-Al2O3 was approximately N ¯ = 2.4 while for the NiWS gallium free catalyst this value was N ¯ = 2.8 . The effect of gallium was more evident when we compared the average mean length for both catalyst, L ¯ was 3.7nm for NiWS/Ga(2.4)-γ-Al2O3 and was L ¯ = 4.6 nm for the NiWS gallium-free catalyst. The mean stacking layer number distribution and mean length distribution of WS2 crystallites are presented in Fig. 10 . 4 Discussion The main objective of this work was to investigate if the addition of Ga to the alumina support could increase the catalytic activity in the hydrodesulfurization reaction of nickel–tungsten sulfided catalysts, as previously observed for cobalt–molybdenum [21], nickel–molybdenum [19] and non-promoted tungsten based catalysts [22]. A series of NiW catalysts was therefore prepared over an industrial alumina support modified by the addition of 0, 0.6, 0.9, 1.2, 1.8, 2.4 and 3.0wt.% of Ga, and these catalysts have been tested in the HDS reactions of dibenzothiophene and 4,6-dimethyldibenzothiophene. Results given, in Fig. 1 for the HDS of dibenzothiophene and in Table 1 for the HDS of 4,6-dimethyldibenzothiophene clearly indicate that gallium addition leads to a significant increase of conversion in both reactions, with a maximum of promotion observed for the NiW/Ga(2.4)-γ-Al2O3 sample. Although these results confirm the interest of gallium as additive to the alumina support, the maximum of activity observed here for addition of 2.4wt.% of gallium for NiW samples was different as compared with the one observed for the WO x /Ga(wt.%)-γ-Al2O3 series in which the maximum of activity was reached for the WO x /Ga(1.09)-γ-Al2O3 catalyst [22]. For supported Co(Ni)Mo(W) sulfided catalysts gain of activity is generally explained by an increase of the dispersion of the active MoS2 (or WS2) phase, by a better sulfidation and by a higher number of promoted sites. In order to understand such an effect for gallium, our catalysts have been characterized by several techniques both in their oxidic state (precursors) and in their sulfided state. As previously done for unpromoted catalysts [22], decomposition of the Raman broad band located between 740 and 1060cm−1 allowed us to calculate the ratio between integrated peak areas of terminals bonds (OWO and WO) and of internal WOW bonds. Variation of this ratio with the gallium content (see Fig. 3) showed that the terminal WO species became more abundant than the WOW internal bonds as the gallium content increased; a relative higher amount of WO bonds in the structure of gallium doped catalysts suggested the presence of higher amounts of highly distorted tetrahedral and octahedral WO x species than in the gallium-free catalyst [22,33,35]. For the NiWO x /Ga(2.4)-γ-Al2O3 catalyst, this ratio was about twice the one calculated for WO x /Ga(1.09)-γ-Al2O3 sample. For the unpromoted tungsten catalysts [22], maximum of activity was also correlated to an increase of this Raman bands ratio and we can therefore assume that for this series the new gain of activity could be also partly explained by an increase on the dispersion of the tungsten species in the oxidic precursor, due to gallium addition. The additional Raman spectroscopy study for Ni/Ga(x)-γ-Al2O3 materials exhibited an increment on the vibration centered at 550cm−1 with the addition of gallium, confirming the affinity of gallium to the tetrahedral sites of alumina. This led to a decrease of the nickel in these sites and inducing, therefore an increase of the octahedral species of nickel. The Nitet/Nioct ratio value calculated for Ni/Ga(0.0)-γ-Al2O3 sample and for Ni/Ga(1.2)-γ-Al2O3 were 0.60 and 0.39 respectively. Since Nioct species are involved in the formation of mixed active NiWS phase [9], these results suggest a higher amount of nickel available for the formation of promoted sites. These results about the nickel species in the oxidic state were also supported by TPR and UV–vis data. Characterization of the catalysts in the sulfided state was first performed by electron microscopy. From HRTEM examinations it appeared clearly that gallium addition induced a decrease of the length of the WS2 crystallites, probably consequence of the higher dispersion of the tungsten in the oxidic state as deduced from Raman analysis. Statistical calculations pointed out to decreases in the average stacking layer and the average mean length (15% and 26% respectively) for the gallium containing catalyst. Regarding any modification in the repartition of tungsten and nickel species, very interesting data were also obtained from XPS analysis. Indeed, XPS characterization for NiW/Ga(x)-γ-Al2O3 sulfide materials in the W4f emission line region indicated a decrease of W4+ species with gallium content. This can be related to an increase of the dispersion of W as a result of increase on W support interactions. Moreover, XPS analysis for the Ni2p energy region led to semi-quantitative information of the NiWS phase. The performed fit on the spectrum indicated a variation on the relative amount of NiWS phase with the gallium content of the materials. The NiW/Ga(2.4)-γ-Al2O3 material exhibited 75% of nickel species involved in the promotion of the “NiWS” active phase instead of only 58% for the NiW/Ga(0.0)-γ-Al2O3 catalyst. Such an increase of the percentage of nickel involved in the “NiWS” phase probably means a better decoration of the WS2 slabs. An attempt was therefore performed to try to correlate HRTEM and XPS data to catalytic activity variations. 4.1 Correlation between XPS, HRTEM and catalytic results In order to correlate the catalytic activities variations with the characteristics of the active phase, we first consider the “geometrical model” proposed by Kasztelan et al. [57]. Assuming that the average mean length L ¯ calculated from HRTEM examinations is the longest dimension of the hexagonal crystallites of WS2 it is possible to relate that length with the number of W edge atoms (W e), presumed to be catalytically active and the total number of W atoms on the slab (W t) can be calculated. These values can be expressed in relation to the number of WW bonds (n) at the edge of the crystallites. According to Vrinat et al. [23], these values are given by the following equations for MoS2-based catalysts: (3) L ¯ = 2 n × d Mo – Mo , (4) Mo t = 3 n 2 + 3 n + 1 , (5) Mo e = 6 n and it is clear that we can also use these equations for the WS2 hexagonal crystallites. The distance d WW was obtained from a recently XAFS characterization work in which a value d WW =0.316nm was reported [25]. The values obtained for n on NiWS/Ga(0.0)-γ-Al2O3 and NiWS/Ga(2.4)-γ-Al2O3 were respectively 7.3 and 5.8 bonds per slab. With these data, values for W t and W e on both materials were calculated and they give access to the W e/W t ratio. Fig. 11 shows the schematic representation of hexagonal crystallites for the two catalysts considered and the evolution of the W e atoms versus the length of the crystallites for hexagonal shape slabs is presented in Fig. 12 . The values of W e/W t obtained from Eqs. (3) to (5) were 0.24 and 0.29 for NiWS/Ga(0.0)-γ-Al2O3 and NiWS/Ga(2.4)-γ-Al2O3 respectively, and these values represent the percentage of W atoms which could be theoretically promoted. EDX analysis performed during the HRTEM experiments was used for the quantification of W and Ni on the surface of the catalysts and the average surface compositions obtained from 10 micrographs are reported in Table 5 . For tungsten, the surface composition corresponded to the tungsten chemical analysis but the nickel and gallium presented a significant decrease probably related with the migration phenomena. However, these values allowed us to determine the real quantity of nickel over the surface of the catalysts and the number of promoted sites could be calculated by combining with the percentage of Ni engaged in the NiWS phase. These data reported in Table 6 clearly show that the number promoted sites per gram of catalyst was higher for the NiWS/Ga(2.4)-γ-Al2O3 sample (15.8×1019) as compared with NiWS/Ga(0.0)-γ-Al2O3 catalyst (8.93×1019). Moreover, these data can be used to assess the percentage of the W e atoms which are really promoted. For the NiWS/Ga(0.0)-γ-Al2O3 we found a value of 62% in good agreement with respect to recent data of literature [8]. Therefore a promotion close to 100% was obtained for the for NiWS/Ga(2.4)-Al2O3 sample. This result clearly illustrated the effect of gallium to increase the number of promoted sites. 5 Conclusions The presence of Ga as an additive on the NiW/-γ-Al2O3 catalysts induced an increase on activity on DBT and 4,6-DMDBT HDS reactions and the maximum activity was observed for the NiW/Ga(2.4)-γ-Al2O3 catalyst. Results of selectivity on HDS of DBT and 4,6-DMDBT suggest that the formation of NiWS active sites was increased by the gallium addition. Raman spectroscopy and HRTEM examinations could partly explained such a gain of activity, these techniques pointed out to a slight change in the distribution of the tungsten species in the oxidic state and a modification on the size of the WS2 crystallites in the sulfided state. However, the TPR, UV–vis, and Raman spectroscopy also indicated a change in the repartition of nickel on the surface of the catalyst, with an increase of the octahedral species assumed to be involved in the formation of the mixed “NiWS” phase. Indeed combination of HRTEM and XPS characterizations of the sulfided catalysts confirmed this assumption since only 62% of the edge tungsten atoms would be promoted for the NiWS/Ga(0.0)-γ-Al2O3. By contrast, a promotion close to 100% was obtained for the for NiWS/Ga(2.4)-γ-Al2O3 sample. Acknowledgments J.N. coredata.dc:description: The effect of gallium over the NiW/γ-Al2O3 catalyst was investigated in the hydrodesulfurization (HDS) of 4,6-dimethyl-dibenzothiophene (4,6-DMDBT). The alumina carrier was modified with gallium by the addition of an aqueous solution of Ga(NO3)3·H2O in order to obtain supports with a nominal composition between 0.0 and 3.0wt.% of Ga. The Ni–W catalysts were prepared with respectively 2.8 W atoms and 1.9 Ni atoms per nm2 of initial surface area for the alumina support. The catalysts were characterized by different techniques such as temperature-programmed reduction, X-ray diffraction, UV–vis, Raman spectroscopy, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy and transmission electron microscopy and they were evaluated in the HDS of 4,6-DMDBT. The highest HDS activity for NiW catalysts was observed when the amount of gallium was 2.4wt.%, improving the value by ca. 90% as compared with that for the NiW gallium-free catalyst. This result was correlated to the effect of Ga over the dispersion of W and Ni entities. Indeed, the amount of WO x particles calculated by the Raman (OWO+WO)/WOW band intensities ratio was the highest for NiW/Ga(2.4)-γ-catalyst and HRTEM examination on the sulfided catalysts showed a decrease for the average stacking number and for the average length of WS2 particles with the gallium content. Moreover, change of the promoter (Ni2+) interaction with the support was induced by the affinity of gallium (at low loadings) to the tetrahedral sites of alumina, inducing an increase of the octahedral species of Ni in the oxidic state of the catalysts as evidenced from UV–vis and to a higher amount of the NiWS mixed phase in the sulfided samples as deduced from XPS analysis.
coredata.dc:title: Hydrodesulfurization of sulfur refractory compounds: Effect of gallium as an additive in NiWS/γ-Al2O3 catalysts
